thread.title: George H.W. Bush gets standing ovation in Super Bowl coin toss that Vegas loved
thread.title_full: George H.W. Bush gets standing ovation in Super Bowl coin toss that Vegas loved

author: Marissa Payne
title: George H.W. Bush gets standing ovation in Super Bowl coin toss that Vegas loved
text:
George H.W. Bush gets standing ovation in Super Bowl coin toss that Vegas loved The inside track on Washington politics. Be the first to know about new stories from PowerPost. Sign up to follow, and we’ll e-mail you free updates as they’re published. You’ll receive free e-mail news updates each time a new story is published. You’re all set! By Marissa Payne By Marissa Payne February 5 at 7:26 PM Follow @marissapayne The former president soaked up the spotlight. (Al Bello/Getty Images) 
For a 92-year-old man who got out of the hospital less than a week ago, former president George H.W. Bush looked pretty great on Sunday when he appeared the Super Bowl for the pregame coin toss. Accompanied by his wife Barbara, the 41st president of the United States got a standing ovation from the packed-in crowd at Houston’s NRG Stadium. Former U.S. President @GeorgeHWBush gets standing ovation prior to #SuperBowl coin toss @NBC10 pic.twitter.com/TfEIqGt3f5 
— Jared Pelletier (@NBC10_Jared) February 5, 2017 
The coin toss itself proved slightly more precarious. The coin left Bush’s hand traveling in a more horizontal direction than vertical to land among the feet of some Atlanta Falcons players, but all turned out well. President George H. W. Bush tosses the coin for #SB51 ! @atlantafalcons win the toss and defer! https://t.co/aFtVZmFEpX 
— NFL (@NFL) February 5, 2017 
The coin toss was fair and landed on tails. With the Patriots having called heads, that meant Atlanta would make the call. The Falcons decided to defer starting with the ball to the second half, so the Patriots began on offense. 
Meanwhile, Vegas bookmakers also won the toss. Thanks to the tails result, they’ll have to pay out a lot less to those who wagered on the prop bet. [ Super Bowl LI prop bets to avoid at all costs, including the coin toss ] 
“It seems there’s the inclination by most to pick heads, and we cringe when that’s the result of the coin toss,” Jay Kornegay, vice president of race and sports at Westgate Las Vegas Superbook, told USA Today last week. “We aren’t going to favor heads and move the line. We know each and every year that more people are going to bet on heads.”
